June 13, 1968
Third Report on Programming for the Disadvantaged
Compiled by Michael Hobbs, ETS Staff
I
Drama for Los Angeles' Spanish-speaking population, consumer education
in Houston, more jobs in South Carolina, riots programs in Rochester, and a
state wide radio and TV participation in Wisconsin are among the many new
programs listed here in ETS' Third Report.
ETS intends to continue to compile and circulate reports about this pro¬
gramming as fast as stations send information to ETS about them. (See also
ETS Managers' Memo Report: Program for Disadvantaged Workshop. )
A great deal of programming on ETV stations might be appealing and useful
to ghetto residents as it is to others in the community. Though it is not designed
as a direct response to the specific needs of the disadvantaged, all the adult
education programs on language, arts, auto mechanics, religion, etc., might
properly be considered as programs serving ghetto audiences. The scope of this
report is limited to programming specifically for and about the disadvantaged and
their problems.
It stands to reason an effective immediate answer to that need can come
in the stations' regular public affairs programs -- rather than a "crash program"
of new production. Also, in the rebroadcast of previous programs which are
particularly suitable for the purpose.
There is increasing emphasis on ghetto problems in programs like WTTW's
"Chicago Roundtable" and National Educational Television's "News in Perspective"
and "Regional Report", and in most of the stations' regular news or interview
programs. Many stations have aired or are rebroadcasting the series of programs
on "The History of the Negro People" and the NET documentaries like "A Time
for Burning", "What is Prejudice", "The Way It Is", "From Protest to Resistance"
"Still a Brother", and "Color Us Black. "
This is a summary of new initiatives -- direct responses with "special"
programming to the challenge of the President's National Advisory Commission
on Civil Disorders.
